text:
If I have a function that needs _some_ arguments from a struct but not all, is it quicker to pass arguments individually or is there no performance penalty for passing the whole struct (assuming it is fully typed, doesn't generate type instability etc.)?

From tests some small tests it appears that there is a performance penalty. Is this something that can be improved by inlining?

Ideally I'd like to pass the full struct to keep the code neat (lots of arguments required). Cheers!

elements.text: If I have a function that needs

Ideally I'd like to pass the full struct to keep the code neat (lots of arguments required). Cheers!

text: structs are passed as pointers, so it should be fast to pass the whole thing

text: Yeah Ok, makes sense. Do you know why it seems to make a difference in my examples above?

text: Well, the code generated is nearly identical, so it looks like the struct is causing an additional lookup, so its slightly slower. But I tried `@inbounds` and the difference seem to vanish, so I'm not sure....

text: I'm not at the computer to test, but sometimes avoiding field access in a loop can make a difference. Here you could try to write `vec1 = ts.a[1]` etc. before the loop and then use `vec1` inside the loop

text:
<@U6QPTG69E> intesting, that did even things up as well.

```function individual(vec1, vec2)
  for i in eachindex(vec1)
    vec2[i] = vec1[i] + 2.0
  end
end

function together(ts::TestStruct)
  vec2 = ts.a2
  vec1 = ts.a1
  for i in eachindex(ts.a1)
    vec2[i] = vec1[i] + 2.0
  end
end

julia> @btime individual($(ts.a1),$(ts.a2))
  4.949 μs (0 allocations: 0 bytes)

julia> @btime together($(ts))
  4.965 μs (0 allocations: 0 bytes)```

elements.text: intesting, that did even things up as well.

function individual(vec1, vec2)
  for i in eachindex(vec1)
    vec2[i] = vec1[i] + 2.0
  end
end

function together(ts::TestStruct)
  vec2 = ts.a2
  vec1 = ts.a1
  for i in eachindex(ts.a1)
    vec2[i] = vec1[i] + 2.0
  end
end

julia> @btime individual($(ts.a1),$(ts.a2))
  4.949 μs (0 allocations: 0 bytes)

julia> @btime together($(ts))
  4.965 μs (0 allocations: 0 bytes)
